positive.review:
I started playing Warframe on September 21st. Now, on November 12th, I've accumulated a total of 466 hours.

The game's addictive potential is [b]NO JOKE[/b].

I wouldn't recommend it to anyone with a family, hobbies, or a purpose in life.

The recent review bombing has left me speechless and really shows that some seriously cannot read or just wait a few days to wait out changes. DE is a godsend in terms of community feedback and communication. They listen and they work on changes the community actually wants. 

Example: UI changes are bad? DE worked on it, improved in less than a week. 
Recoil changes aren´t good? DE worked on it and gave us an extra Toggle in less than a week. 
Damage attenuation is annoying and kills the fun? Good, DE changed it and made it better, now also only bosses have it which makes a lot more sense as well. 
A character is bad, needs a REWORK? DE worked on them, made em better, even with new abilities.

It just takes TIME which many people do not seem to get. Coding and testing takes time. After they released an update, there is usually a lot of hotfixes A DAY, which shows, they´re actively listening to the community. They even play the game themselves, the community managers are often seen in game, not just in chats but actually playing the missions. 

Some people have been used to DE, an actual GOOD development team, for too long and it shows. Every time some minor bug comes up, people cry, even though its CLEAR that DE will effectively work on it as fast they can the moment they get the feedback or backlash. 

People cannot, READ! Damage got massively BUFFED and they talk about nerfs. 
The community is often really helpful but goddamn, do they need to learn how to read/ start reading and UNDERSTANDING patch notes.

I´ve been playing this game for a long time, on console and pc. I´ve been there almost since the beginning and its improved A LOT. They´re even effectively working on improving new player experience while also keeping the "OG" players in mind. 

They´re also working on improving older content, which of course takes a lot of time. 

This is one of the few games where i would NOT advice listening to the negative reviews and just test things out yourself. IT IS ALL FREE after all. the community WILL help you if you need it and there is clans that will accept and guide you through things if needed. New player experience is as good as ever right now and is only going to improve further. 

Don´t rush, take your time, there is no "FOMO". You can earn everything for FREE. Some might cry about the amount of grind/ time things take but its honestly not even close to being bad. Its a LOOTER SHOOTER, expect a grind!

Where do i even begin with this. This game is the first ever game that im about to cross 1000hrs in. I feel that alone says about how addictive it can get to play this (even more so with other people).

Now ofcourse there will be moments where you'll feel burnt out or have sheer bad luck, not getting the drops you wanted, and for that i say it is completely okay to take a break. Remember it is a game you play for your enjoyment.
 
Another thing to add to the last point, about 90% (give or take) of the stuff in the game is f2p friendly (granted you have to grind for it) thanks to the wonderful addition of the trading system which even allows you to exchange the game's premium currency. Not only that but there is no FOMO as well (well except mabye a tiny amount of items).

All in all, frame go zoom, gun go brrt and enemies go kaboom.

Now, i must be on my way to get more Tellurium.

It is very grind heavy but there is no fomo(anymore) and everything besides a few "mistakes"(Founders, and the original heirlooms) are obtainable via recurring events, prime resurgence, or just by playing(year round). It is possible to obtain a meta build without paying a dime, the only "pay to win" is the true endgame-fashionframe... And slots. Besides that it is pay to skip the grind. 
Also not to maintain you can trade stuff you don't want to get plat a good portion of the time.

Outside of the free to play friendly slogan, the gameplay is very nice. There is basically a frame and weapon for everyone... I do mean everyone... Want a beam sure, want split beams sure, wanna deal pure fire and burn a enemy sure, wanna mind control enemies there is a frame and a status(for weapons) that is just for that, wanna blow up enemies with a big gun-well you can do that in the sky missions and later deploy that big gun(plus their is regular boom sticks aka launchers), wanna shotgun while surviving fifty trillion hits. You can just pick a flavor(glutton tank, absolute tank, health regen tank, shield mommy, etc)

Besides that the parkour is good, and when you decide to stay hooked... Well lets say you be reworded with the best story missions in a f2p game ever. 

This game has years of polish and you should not brush it off as pay to win despite the grind as that is so far from the truth you are spitting in the devs face. Just if you can survive the grind, you will like the game if you can find the loadout you like for your perferred playstyle :3

To say "you're a space ninja" just doesn't communicate the actual power fantasy this game drops you into.

The absolutely insane variety of different weapons and warframes, with all the different ways you can customize and min-max your playstyle is what really draws me to this game. There always seems to be more to discover even after playing this game for more then 6000 hrs (at the point of writing this).

There are so many different mechanics, effects and rules you can bend and theory-craft around that it literally took me years to get around to, play around for myself or even understand them.

For me, in essence, Warframe is an optimization game. 
While you can indeed do pretty much everything with that one warframe and that specific gun, the game encourages you to adapt, experiment and optimize for the situation.

Testing and discovering new cool ways to play this game is what kept me around and I wholeheartedly recommend this game to that specific subset of people that like optimizing and theory-crafting as much as I do.

The story is pretty unique, both stylishly and narratively. It draws inspiration from spirituality, philosophy and as well from many different established science fiction themes. In other words - the story is weird, the world and locations are weird - I like that. It provoked thought and many story moments stayed with me for years later.

Besides, the community is nice. The devs listen to the players. 
The game is constantly worked on and updated regularly (new content every ~3 months). For a totally free game its unheard of. The monetization model that does exist is fair and not greedy, while allowing the player to trade with other players and get everything via effort and time. Other game developers should all take a page from Warframe's book in that regard.

I do wish for a way to change and customize the UI via addons that will allow me to track buffs, effects and timers better (like in WoW).

In short, Warframe perfectly blends action, strategy, and RPG elements—it’s absolutely amazing.

Warframe is an interesting distraction for folks who tired of other paid MMOs. It's absolutely worth a 50-100 stroll for free, and that's the best thing I can say about it. The concept is great, the content is expansive, and the graphics/artwork are very close to today's standards (well, maybe 2022-ish). 

The best thing I can say about this game is the lack of in-your-face monetization. While there are options to quickly move ahead with gear, many of the early equipment becomes available just by playing. You can easily get 30+ hours out of this game just playing a space ninja. And that's why it still exists with a higher concurrent player base than many AAA titles released in the past year. 

The problem with Warframe is that it's early game gives you a notion that you can farily grind everything out. But after 130+ hours, I can tell you that is not the case. And the loop they get you addicted to is the same as mobile gaming from the early 2010s. They've just done a far better job hiding the time gates behind perceived power creeps during the first 100 hours. But once you're into the MR10+ range, you start to realize the need to buy plat to advance at a decent rate. 

This isn't to say you can't just face grind everything till your heart's content. Because you can. And again, the monetization isn't all that predatory. But the game is constantly tempting you to spend plat to speed up a build in order to level up your MR. In some ways, it's an amazing F2P system and doesn't penalize players for just wanted to blow shit up for a few hours a week. In others, it preys on the minority of players that really do want to progress and aren't willing to wait for a new warframe, weapon, etc. to be completed. 

I'm glad I played it, got a ton of value for next to nothing. But you start to realize the king has no clothes about 100+ hours in and that the grind ahead is going to cost you a decade of time or $1K of money.

Superb fast gunplay meets great melee meets parkour space ninja's with magic. And it's viable solo and very ready to matchmake coop pve. Wrapped in power fantasy that still challenges you. [b]And it succeeds at all of it.[/b]

[b]F2P but not pay to win[/b] - in fact, buying too much actually kinda deprives you. But a little here and there keeps both the game and excellent player economy going. Part of what keeps this game going strong is how the dev's didn't rake in the dough, but instead set it up so it's best to take purchase currency and buy items from players rather than the store. Earning pay currency is very viable, even for early-mid game players. Because of this, I've happily supported the game many times.

Normally, melee wrecks shooters. Not here. The seamless transition combined with the movement makes for a beautiful combo:
Brap brap... mag runs out, quick slide sword spin, reload.
Swoop in from above, surprise ground slam, slash slash, brap brap. It's great.

Plenty of different settings (some are surprisingly intricate and very stylish for their alien architecture).
Plenty of mission types, especially as you progress, though most are at their core focused around shooting. This is one of the few games where not only do I not hate the defense missions, they are actually one of my favorite modes. (as soon as you can earn him, use frost bubble shield)

But I haven't told you what you do in the game: At it's core, it's a fast paced PVE looter-shooter.
1. plenty of solo story arcs/missions (some are pretty cinematic).
2. jumping into missions with players.
common missions are (shoot and fight to) reach objectives, eliminate enemies, defend things, sneak in & infiltrate and hack or sabotage/blow up things, reach and defeat a boss, some open world locations, and a number of endless modes where you have to decide how far to push your capabilites)
3. helping and/or being helped (including taxi and carry to things you haven't unlocked yet). Notably helpful community and useful chat. Struggling with a boss, people will help if you ask.
4. earning exp to level up your warframes, weapons, pets, and "mastery rank" (unlocks new items and other bonuses)
5. mods. The heart of the game is finding, trading, earning, then upgrading mods and putting them on your warframes and weapons to make interesting and increasingly powerful builds.
6. going after more warframes, finding your favorite combo's and really customizing your play styles (since you will have several go to's for different game modes)
7. unlock the whole starchart and complete stories to unlock more modes and challenges.
8. as with customizing your loadouts, it becomes natural to personalize your warframes, ships, & gear too. Why play vanilla Volt, when I can make him jet black and shoot red lightning? Nidus plays like Carnage, so I'm going to make him look like Carnage too.
Think of it this way: if you can, you buy a car you like and in a color you like. and it's satisfying. How much more satisfying would it be if you pieced it together and picked every color?

Tips for new players:
1. Start with the regular/tenno path. (do Duviri later, after you've cleared a planet or 2).
Eventually you will be able to get the frames you didn't choose, but it will be a while. All will melee, so don't think you need Excalibur for that. You are choosing your superpowers. (Don't fret it, even if Volt is best choice)
Excal = swords and sword dash super power (remember you can already sword slide with any frame)
Volt = emperor palpatine + super speed + energy shield (helps with def and can carry and shooting through = damage boost!) + nuke
Mag = more complex (better for a returning player - if they don't take volt), damage protection, status infliction, all useful and powerful if you know when and how to use them, but lacks the wow feeling of excal and volt. (honestly they should change mag out for some other frame to start with)

2. don't let the game dupe you into wasting your starting free Platinum to rush item construction. Use it for a couple weapon slots and then a warframe slot. (you can earn more in nightware rewards)

3. Open the menu and at the upper left near your name - set it to solo or friends only, just for the first number of missions (otherwise more experienced players will blast through before you even know what was happening) when it starts getting hard (defense or boss missions) then swap it to public and leave it there. (game is more fun with people)

4. ask for help. They even have a helpful chat bot, so you can ask "where is [item name]?" and it will tell you what planet and where to get it.

5. once you freak out about build times, realize you get a flow of items making, so there is something ready most of the time. then build time rarely matters. on that: don't buy weapons or warframes for platinum. Instead but the blueprints for credits (cheap easy earn currency) then build them.
(exception: buying one extra frame early is nice. Not needed, but nice. I recommend Nidus or Nekros or Khora)

6. when you get to the point where your damage feels weak and you need help, doubling up on the same category of damage is weaker vs different types that multiply:
+%dmg +%dmg + % dmg = weaker than
+%dmg + elem + multishot + crit + firerate = super extra strong

7. sell weapons you've maxed rank (30) to clear space for new unless it's something powerful you need or special or a crafting ingredient. to do so, open menu, equipment, inventory, then tab over to the weapons. You get no benefit to make a duplicate and try to level that again (which is why you can hide owned and Mastered in the store page where you buy blueprints)

I’ve been playing Warframe on and off for a while now, and every time I come back, I’m surprised at how much it’s grown. The movement and combat feel incredibly smooth — nothing else really compares once you get used to sliding, bullet jumping, and slicing through enemies at high speed.

What I really love is how much freedom the game gives you. You can play solo or with friends, take it slow and explore, or just jump into fast missions and farm gear. The amount of customization is insane — from the Warframes themselves to weapons and even how your ship looks.

The devs actually care about the game too; they keep adding new content and updating old stuff. It’s one of those rare free games that doesn’t feel pay-to-win  you can earn everything just by playing.

Overall, it’s one of the most rewarding games I’ve played, especially if you like sci-fi and fast-paced action. Definitely worth giving a shot, even in 2025.

Note: There is no Mac or Linux client currently available. One can only imagine the scene unfolding in some small office somewhere, where the developers sit among stacks of teacups and half-eaten biscuits, staring at screens with the kind of solemn concentration usually reserved for chess grandmasters or people trying to decide which cake to have with their afternoon tea. Somewhere in the corner MacBooks and Linux machines sit quietly, like well-mannered guests who have arrived too early to a party and are politely pretending not to notice that the door is firmly closed in their faces. The developers glance at them, sip their tea, and shrug in a way that is both mysterious and slightly charming, as if to say, 'Perhaps another day, my dear friends, perhaps another day.'

Meanwhile the Windows users are clicking merrily away, probably humming a tune, completely unaware that elsewhere the air is heavy with wistfulness and quiet despair. One imagines the Mac and Linux folk staring out of rain-spattered windows, lost in thought, contemplating the cruel injustice of their situation while pigeons strut purposefully along the wet pavement, seemingly smug in their freedom to come and go as they please. A cat curls on a radiator, its tail twitching in rhythm with the melancholy, and a tea kettle whistles in the distance, perhaps in solidarity.

Perhaps they write letters to themselves, or to no one in particular, small haikus about incompatibility and longing, or sketch delicate penguins trudging nobly through endless fields of code, dressed for the cold yet never complaining. Perhaps they rehearse polite speeches for when they are finally acknowledged, making sure to bow slightly before every sentence and to apologise in advance for taking up too much bandwidth.

It is all very civilized, like a queue in a foggy English town that stretches on forever, where nobody complains even though they might be waiting hours, because manners are more important than comfort. Yet in this waiting, in the polite sighs and soft tea slurps, there is a strange sort of beauty. A quiet absurd beauty, like a cucumber sandwich left on the windowsill that is still edible but slightly sad, or a teacup perched precariously on the edge of a table daring gravity to intervene while no one quite watches. It is tragic and delightful at once, like a very polite comedy in which the plot may never resolve, but everyone continues to sip tea and smile faintly, knowing that life, software incompatibility, and pigeons will march on regardless.

And perhaps, just perhaps, one day a soft murmur will ripple through the office, biscuits will be nibbled in celebration, and Mac and Linux machines will be invited inside. Until then, we wait, we sigh, we sip, and we imagine penguins in bowler hats conducting very serious business meetings in tiny boardrooms full of glowing monitors, utterly dignified and entirely British.

I made the switch to PC seven months ago, and one of the first games I got on here was Warframe. I started playing almost ten years ago when I was in middle school, and the game was very different back then. Being around to watch it grow, continuing to play it with friends every now and again has really put into perspective just how truly awesome the developers and the game really is. It is intimidating at first, trying to understand the mod system, build crafting, the grinds that you get to experience for new weapons, materials, new frames to place, etc. After that main hurdle though, it's a nice time to relax and enjoy just blowing things up and watching numbers fill your screen.

As long as Digital Extremes continues to support Warframe and future titles like their sister project Soulframe, I'll always recommend someone to at least try them.

Bruh… Warframe had me feelin’ like I got adopted by space gods and thrown into a turbo-galactic daycare where everybody got rockets for legs.

From the moment I loaded in, I’m slicin’, slidin’, zoomin’ — whole game feel like parkour on alien Adderall. Movin’ so fast my monitor started speakin’ fluent Twizzy.

The frames go CRAZY too. Every suit look like a luxury spaceship with anger issues. Abilities hittin’ like dimensional tax fraud — no explanation, just BOOM, everything gone.

Upgrade system? Don’t even get me started. Mods stacked so high I swear I was buildin’ the Ziggurat of Zaiborgs. My damage numbers ain’t even numbers anymore, they glyphs from ancient turbo runes.

And the grind? Bro I LOVE the grind. I’m doin’ missions at 4AM like
“One more relic, twin… one more… Twizzy can’t sleep till the prime is built.”

Community goated too. Everyone movin’ like semi-sentient hoverboards, helpin’ you farm, showin’ you builds, speakin’ in riddles and DPS math.

This game so fire it turned my PC fans into afterburners.

7/10 — this that warp-drive, star-slicer, intergalactic-Tonka simulator. Twizzy certified.
9/10, game is basically destiny 2 but better in every way, including that EVERYTHING in the game (except some skins) can be obtained for free!

Fun game, but better with friends. Gets kinda grindy at times (especially later on), but never that bad and there are so many things you can do if you get bored of one type of activity. I LOVE that you can earn premium paid currency without paying a dime into the game. I do recommend you support the devs if you like the game enough to buy skins or want to skip some of the effort (while most things don't take too much effort proportional to the reward, there are a small few things that take a ton of effort compared to the reward that you might want to pay to skip), but it's nice to be able to put in some enjoyable effort to get Prime components to trade with people in exchange for their premium currency (that they also traded or paid for).

It's no BG3 or Cyberpunk of course, but it's probably one of the best games out there of its genre (and it's not trying to be BG3 or Cyberpunk, rather it's trying to just be better than Genshin or WOW, which I'd say it succeeds at overall). 8/10

By far my most played game. And with good reason.
Here's what I think about it:

Positives:
1) Variety ( LOTS of warframes, guns, melees, mods, builds etc. )
2) A LOT of content ( Warframe came out almost 13 years ago. You can only imagine how much content you've got to cover )
3) Customization ( I already mentioned builds, which is a form of customization, but there's also A LOT of skins, all sort of " mounts ", ships, back attachments, color palettes etc. )
4) F2P ( Not only is the game F2P, but you can also earn the premium currency, Platinum, by trading with other players )
5) The community is probably the best I've seen in any game. I've been given a lot of advices and stuff by random players. Like for example the Ignis Wraith blueprint.
6) Satisfying combat ( Fast, parkour like movements and goddamn you feel powerful when you wipe an entire room full of enemies )
7) It runs well
8) Audio ( Maybe the graphics are a bit outdated but the music is top notch )

Negatives:
1) A bit overwhelming for a new player ( There's all sort of currencies and materials and etc. )
2) At some point, after many hundred hours, you wake up and you realize you're overpowered and that there's very few things in the game that are remotely challenging anymore.
3) It has gotten better now, but for the longest time some of the warframes were very underwhelming while others can do literally all the content in the game. This isn't a big problem, but I thought I'd just mention it.
4) It can be a bit grindy depending on how much time you've got on your hands. Although in my opinion it is better than other similar games
5) Time-gating ( Long crafting duration, things that you can only do once a week etc. )

Warframe is the game where I start a mission thinking it’ll be chill, then suddenly I’m a space ninja flying through walls, shooting lasers, and somehow killing 200 enemies before my brain catches up. Warframe is the only game where you play as a hyperactive space ninja who can backflip through ten rooms, vaporize 40 enemies, and still somehow forget what the actual mission objective was. The movement is buttery smooth, the combat is explosive, and the story goes from “kinda cool” to “WHAT DID I JUST WITNESS?” in record time.

You’ll spend hours grinding for a weapon, then immediately start grinding for another weapon you didn’t even know existed. And yet — it never feels bad. Warframe is basically a free-to-play fever dream powered by caffeine, loot, and parkour.

Final verdict: 10/10 — Fast, fun, overwhelming, and somehow comforting. Space ninja therapy.

Honest review for someone that played it a good amount of time for a beginner. 
The Thing is I love games that satisfy you with the feeling of "I have achieved something" and warframe is definitly a game of this kind. But... only for a span of time, and its different for all people cause as long as you can hold on to the illusion that the story doesnt matter, and that you dont need to invest too much time into it, you are all good. Everybody is different at having the ability or capacity to hold on to their illusion. 

On my behalf, I am done. I am done pretending that the story is somehow good, cause its shit. I am done pretending that the crafting time is somehow okey. I am done pretending that getting units is easy. Yeah maybe for someone playing 1000 of hours, after that everything seems easy. I am also done with the level design, the "oh the levels are all random so good" bullshit comments. This game is really like a drug, but only as long as you can uphold the illusion I mentioned earlier.

OK, so this review is a long time coming. I have been playing warframe for a very long time across multiple platforms. I have seen it change into something that doesn't feel like the game I have so many fond memories of.

At it's core, you play as a character called a tenno who controls alien ninja war machines called warframes. The gameplay is genuinely great and one of the reasons I love the game so much. It's fast paced, grindy, and there is a lot to do. I love games with a good RNG farming system. Also, its hard to beat a free game with how much is in it.

Since the change in leadership and their creative direction, the game is moving away from the high octane shooter looter that I feel many people play the game for. What have they added in recent updates? More fun and interesting content? More high adrenaline missions to farm for rare items? More story that explains the backstory of the star system you play in? No... a dating sim... Why a dating sim in a game about alien ninja war machines ripping through hordes of enemies? What a fantastic question. The Drifter is lame and this isn't why I play the game. If I wanted to go on a date, I would go touch grass. I didn't enjoy the 1999 questline, you can't even beat it without making friends with all of the NPCs in the new area which was obnoxious (because the power of friendship... I guess? idk).

One saying in the game is that "fashion-frame is the end game" which I agree with. There are tons of cool ways to customize your character. In recent updates, the developers have traded cool for sexy and awesome for perverted. I can't be the only person on the planet who feels like this is getting too common everywhere. I would expect this stuff out of a crappy mobile game, not here. It's just gross. For specifics, I am referring to things like the Valkyr and Ember heirloom skins. I am just kinda over it. You want to see for yourself how the game has changed in this aspect? Look at Nova, one of the oldest frames, then look at those heirloom skins again. or better yet, look at base Ember and then look at her heirloom skin. Modesty has left everywhere in favor of selling sex. Sometimes I don't even blame them though because all the basement dwellers in the in game chat seem to enjoy being pervy and talking about how much cake their frame has. Maybe I am in the minority on this one, who knows or cares anyway I guess.

The story is starting to make less and less sense as well. Many of the new "story" quests don't actually give any meaningful insights to the game, they just keep adding new crap. Jade shadows for example... a preggo frame? Really? Just why? Did you just need to check a box? The warframes are literally machines. I don't get it. The duviri paradox questline is just some sped kid's fever dream that you get stuck in... somehow... I would just rather have something coherent that ties other things in the universe together where I feel like they don't, they just keep adding more fluff.

The game is fun, but it just isn't the same. The silver lining is that you can just simply not interact with parts of the story you don't like, but the fact that they are even in the game is just strange to me. I played Warframe for years and I've always tried to get people into it, but more and more as time progresses I have to add caveats. You can play a huge open exploration map... unfortuantely half the mining nodes are bugged or placed on the roof where you cant get them. You can play as nearly 100 characters. It takes 8 hours of farming each one but hey you can kinda technically do that thing eventually in three years of playing 8 hours daily. All of the original frames will get nerfed and youll have to unlock new variants like Excalibur Umbra to do anything, following endless story missions that are disperate from one another and dont feel like they contribute to a central story. One second youre killing Vay Hek and the next second hes been dead for 3 years and his zombie is back. The pacing has become an absolute nightmare. There is feature bloat on top of the existing feature bloat and its very easy to break the flow and sequence of the story and be left in narrative limbo wondering what the heck is going on, whos working for who, and why I should even care when nothing has any consequences because you're just space jesus anyway. I've played a lot of the new content (unlocked Nokko, sorta fun, functionally useless compared to similar frames that work a lot less for the same result, but being immortal is cool) and done the Call of the Tempestrati, which was an absolutely abysmal experience about an edgelord, a hamfisted variant of phoenix from valorant, token asian female, token dominatrix female and a 90s tech nerd. Its gonna be tough hacking through all of that trash and dealing with those characters who have been done to death so many times I dont remember a single one of their names. Phoenix is called something like "Clancy" and has a sissy white guy name but thats literally all I remember about these characters im apparently supposed to like according to the story. They are utterly forgettable. The samurai guy has a scar over his eye. The british gangster guy unironically says "SKKKRAAAA" like youre in a battle with Big Shaq. They all call your character "Marty" which is a really funny reference to that joke they did two hours ago where one of the characters called you "Marty McFlea" because of your time travelling.

As someone who favors single-player games, I kind of enjoyed my time so far. The story is intriguing and the community has been nice up to this point.

But there are a few issues that make the experience a no-no for me.

[-] [b]Enemies keep respawning in areas I've already cleared.[/b] This one is negligible and I get it that the game doesn't want me to ever feel like the map is empty, but there's a difference between a map being empty and being empty because I cleared it.

[--] I tried playing in public, which means people may join me on a mission when I start one, and I had nothing but bad experiences that forced me to go solo. [b]People ignore me greeting them and directly go for the mission objective,[/b] whereas I prefer to take my time and explore the area at my own pace. Not even a "Hello."

[--] [b]A lot of things are taken for granted and information is scattered around without any logic.[/b] Let's take for example the help text that explains Polarities. It's shown after a looong list of help texts for no apparent reason, not to mention I don't even have the certainty that it's there in the first place unless I loop through them all. Overall not a great new-player experience. Every piece of information in this game is placed in a list of tooltips that you read by continuously pressing the same button, which does not play really well in my opinion.

[---] [b]Enemies can see me through closed doors and on different height levels.[/b] Enough said here. Often the doors are also already open due to enemies standing too close, which makes them spot me immediately. I am supposed to open the doors, not them. And if they do it should be because I somehow alerted them and not because they were walking around there.

[---] [b]My play style is completely invalidated by multiple factors.[/b] I prefer to play stealthy from a distance rather than melee the whole level, but that's never actually possible. Rooms are FILLED with alarm stations to the extent that even preventing one enemy from triggering one is pointless as there is another in the backroom easily accessible for the others. Not to mention you CANNOT disable an alarm station beforehand.

I put around 1700 hours into Warframe. I grinded everything, pushed through every wall, aimed for endgame, and genuinely loved it. Then suddenly — boom — I’m permanently banned for a chat argument from months ago. Someone provoked me, insulted me, kept poking at me, and I finally reacted. One moment, one sentence — and apparently 1700 hours don’t matter. For some people that’s literally years of grind wiped out instantly.

Here’s the part people really need to understand — because I didn’t, until it was too late:
You don’t need to be insulting someone.
You don’t need to mean anything malicious.
You can literally be joking with your own friends.
You can say something that wasn’t intended to offend anyone at all.
And guess what?
A single moment, a single slip-up, one stupid sentence in clan chat or squad chat — and months later it can still come back and obliterate your entire account. No warning, no “hey, don’t say that,” no nothing. Just instant permanent deletion.
They don’t hand out mutes.
They don’t hand out temporary timeouts.
They go straight for “remove this player from existence.”

After my ban, I started digging into it — and it turns out this nonsense is everywhere. People get banned for harmless jokes, friendly sarcasm, or something taken completely out of context. Even long-term players with perfect histories get wiped instantly. The system doesn’t care what you meant or who you were talking to — it just swings the hammer without thinking.

And here’s the part that really makes you laugh (or rage):
Loyalty means absolutely NOTHING.
1700 hours? Doesn’t matter.
3000 hours? Doesn’t matter.
5000 hours? Still doesn’t matter.
You can be the most dedicated, helpful, legitimate player ever — if you type one wrong word once, even if it wasn’t serious, even if it was friendly banter, even if you were DEFENDING yourself, the system will nuke your account without hesitation. Being loyal? Forget it.

Reaching out to support?
Prepare yourself.
You’ll get the most robotic, emotionless replies imaginable. It’s like they have a menu of preset responses and pick one at random. There’s no real conversation, no context, no attempt to understand anything. You might as well send your ticket to a refrigerator — at least it won’t pretend it cares while giving you copy-paste nonsense.

Let’s be clear: rules are fine. But going straight to PERMANENT deletion over a dumb moment, a sarcastic joke, or a heated argument is ridiculous. It’s like handing someone a life sentence for arguing in a supermarket. Humans joke. Humans argue. Humans get annoyed. Humans make mistakes. But in Warframe? You’re expected to be a flawless, emotionless robot 24/7.

And the most ridiculous part?
Chat is basically the backbone of the entire game.
Trading, recruiting, clans, squads, help channels — without chat, Warframe would collapse. The game relies on communication. Yet the same system that keeps the community alive is also the fastest way to lose your entire account. Want to enjoy the game? Stay away from chat. But without chat… what exactly are you left with?
The irony is painful.

Honestly, once the shock faded, I almost felt relieved. Because the truth? The grind is brutal. I genuinely have no idea how new players survive without spending money. Free-to-play players? Prepare for thousands of hours of grinding. I spent some money — not even much — and even then I barely touched endgame. Without paying, I’d probably still be stuck in the early star chart.

So here’s the final warning:
Warframe is an incredible game — one of the best gameplay experiences out there.
But the chat system?
It’s a landmine waiting for you to step on it.
Step on it once — even by accident, even joking with friends — and your entire account evaporates.

If you choose to play:
Enjoy the gameplay.
Enjoy the combat.
Enjoy the world.
But be careful — because ONE single word can cost you everything you ever earned.

I have been playing Warframe as a free to play player since 2015, I like the game but I have to admit I still can't recommend it to anyone.
There are still a lot of issues that have existed for years that have not gotten fixed or properly addressed like gameplay bugs. 
I've had this specific issue for a long time, I'll switch to my operator and sometimes I get locked into a glitchy run animation and I can't use abilities or any weapons until I use a console command or die to get out of it.

I can honestly look past this issue, the main problem is that a lot of warframe's content is just more beneficial to run with squads or at the very least with randoms so you have to experience P2P disconnects unless you have a trusted squad to run with.

I had a terrible experience when I was running relic missions with random players on survival missions on steel path and a player in my squad wanted to extract at 5 minutes so he tried extracting but couldn't because he didn't mod his equipment properly and he used all his revives.

I noticed this person was the host as well, and when he realized the rest of the squad didn't want to extract, he left or disconnected and caused a host migration which failed and disconnected my entire squad so I couldn't even relic share with the other two who got disconnected.

I don't blame this person, I blame the fact that warframe has used player hosted sessions for years to reduce costs which has been understandable at one point but now that Digital Extremes announced their new game which could also have P2P and not to mention already that Digital Extremes is making $25 to $141 million annually.

if your previous games are known to have issues like these, how can I trust that your new game won't have these exact same issues? Or if they will ever get fixed?

I also felt that the recently added "The Teacher" quest did not explain the importance of ability strength, duration and range which I can see a lot of new players still not understanding how modding works. Hopefully they wont end up like the guy who caused a host migration.
Warframe is a great game, especially for someone who doesn't want to spend a lot of money on a game. I just can't recommend it for newer players until these issues get fixed.
